newsitem.title: USA: Miami Heat $165 mln arena seen using private money.
newsitem.headline: Miami Heat $165 mln arena seen using private money.

text.p: The Miami Heat signed a letter of agreement Friday to use private money, instead of tax-supported revenue bonds, to build a new $165 million arena for the basketball team.

Details were incomplete, but Dade County Mayor Alex Penalas said the agreement still calls for the arena to be built on waterfront park land owned by the county. The facility would be owned by the county, but paid for and managed by the Heat.
"Tax dollars will not be used," Penelas said.
The agreement comes four days before a voter referendum on a proposal to block construction of the new arena on the park land adjacent to the Port of Miami.
Polls suggested the project would fail if tax money were used for the arena, but would pass if the facility was privately financed.
The original financing plan called for the Miami Sports Authority to issue revenue bonds backed with sales taxes, hotel taxes and a $50 million payment from the team.
Although recent polls showed the team was gaining support, team owner Mickey Arison said the outcome of the referendum was uncertain.
"It was a close call. It was still a 50-50 shot," he said at a news conference announcing the agreement.
The referendum was placed on the ballot via petitions from citizens who opposed the use of tax money and the use of public park property for the new arena.
The referendum will still take place on Tuesday, and arena construction could be blocked if voters prohibit the use of the land.

The ballot language, which was the subject of a court challenge, does not ask voters to approve the project but rather whether they want to prohibit it. That means those who support the measure must vote 'no' and opponents must vote 'yes' to block it.
